title: What college math class should I take if I need a math credit but suck at math? - Quora

response.answer_text: My department chair, a mathematician, made an offer to his intro math classes: if no one said “I’m bad at math” (or something similar) in class, he would give them all some extra credit. Get that thought out of your head, or you’ll psych yourself out. That’s what I did, and trust me, it didn’t turn out well. I had a lot of fear and anxiety about mathematics because I let myself believe this. Also, whatever math class you take, put in the time. I just wrote Joshua Gross's answer to What is the golden rule for studying?, and they’re all about how much time is necessary. I teach courses that count as mathematics general education requirements, and trust me when I say that the biggest issue is how much time students commit. That may be far more time than you like, and it may be more time than the toughest course in your major (for you), but it’s nonetheless true. Given the two considerations, picking the class should not be hard. You should have a relatively small number of courses that satisfy this requirement. The requirements are specific to your school, but here’s a list of the common ones: Precalculus - this continues from high school mathematics (algebra, geometry, trigonometry) and is mostly taken by students who need calculus; it may be a minimum requirementCalculus with analytical geometry, also known as General Calculus, Calculus for Science and Engineering, or just Calculus; this will include trigonometry and focus on problems like filling and emptying containers, because it’s used in physical sciences and engineeringBusiness calculus, which is more “applied”, but the application is in business and looks at things like how investments might grow over time; there’s typically little trigonometryStatistics, or probability and statistics: there may well be a dozen different stats classes you can take for this requirement (or none), and if so, ask around for recommendations; this is the most commonly used form of mathematicsA concepts in mathematics course, which will cover multiple areas, but the specifics will depend on the professor and semester

I would actually avoid any “counting for credit” classes, of the sort created for people who are terrible at math. Those classes can also be terribly confusing. I have a master’s in math and when one student showed me his homework from a “math for jocks” class, I couldn’t make heads or tails of it! It would have been boringly easy if I had been sitting in the class and had some context, but outside of it, it looked downright incoherent. I’d recommend the lowest level of regular math available, if math in general is giving you trouble. However, if you can find an easy class in linear algebra, or discrete math, those might be easier than say Calc 1. It’s kind of a crapshoot though, so check out what people say about the difficulty level of classes at your school in particular. Good luck!
